annotation.TEXT: As far as Blade Man goes, he still has a pretty simple pattern. He'll stay on the other side of the room, constantly jumping an chucking blades at you. When the crusher is high enough, he'll jump to the center of the room and throw out three blades before going back to his normal spot. Notably, he actually has a second phase (which you'll only face if you've beaten Bit Man first, which ties in with this game's stage changing mechanics).

Dynamo Wrecker got a pretty significant overhaul. Rather than bouncing along when fired, it now blows up after touching anything. It also releases three extra bombs that cause even more explosions, making it a great option for taking out enemies with shields (or ones that generally have more HP).

Razor Blade didn't seem to receive any major changes, but then again, it wasn't really in need of such. It still curves upwards, and it's useful for hitting enemies that are out of your way (although Shark Boomerang can also serve the same purpose as well).

Here's how it works: When you beat a boss, the level next to their's (clockwise in terms of position) on the stage select screen will have a slightly different border around the boss' mugshot. Every level has two paths in it, and the border change signals that the secondary path in that stage has been opened. This not only leads to new sections of levels, but also the WAVE letters and Doc Robot boss doors (for reference, the four corner levels hold the WAVE letters, while the cardinal stages have Doc Robot bosses).
Two intentional deaths in the same video? You'd think I was trying to get free level up's from Yoel (and on that note, you can probably tell I've been playing way too much Dark Souls 3 lately).

As said before, this game isn't without its faults...and that mainly comes in the form of glitches. I don't know how or why this happened, but the transition to the next screen just wouldn't trigger here. Definitely something that needs to be looked into (especially if it turns out that this isn't the only spot it can happen in).

Kind of a weird decision for an intro boss at first glance, but after thinking about it, it actually makes sense in relation to the original DOS games. After all, the first level in that game had you running away from a jumping cat robot (then again, it could have been a dog. It's pretty hard to tell with those graphics).

I'm not even sure how I survived that last attack there, but I'll roll with it, along with the new version of Binary Dash. Aside from having a proper demonstration this time around, this weapon actually has two different functions: A normal projectile, and the actual dash itself (which seems to create a clone, just as Bit Man did).

Back to the subject of stage changes, though: Notice that these crushers are from Blade Man's stage? A neat design choice with these branching paths is that they borrow elements from the level that triggered the new path to open. Going off this, you can expect to see these magnets in Torch Man's stage later on.

Starting off with the basic run-down: Mega Man's overall feel in this game has been dramatically improved. He doesn't feel quite as floaty and disjointed as he did in the original. The slide is still a bit iffy, but thankfully it isn't that much of a hindrance. The levels have gotten some overhauls in a few areas, along with screen transitions being much faster this time around. Speaking of levels though, this game now has an intro stage (albeit, it's a very strong candidate for shortest intro stage ever).

Another really notable change in this version is that Dyna Man and Sonic Man's stages have been switched. Definitely a good change, seeing as they now fit more with the themes of the bosses. On that note however, I should go over the stage changing mechanic mentioned before, seeing as this is the first level where it comes into play.

Hooray for recklessness. I figured that since I had four lives, I may as well power through it and take an unintentional death at the boss. Naturally though, things always get a bit scary when you're at low health and have just a few more enemies to contend with.

While I can't attribute the nickname "Glitch Buckler" to this weapon anymore (seeing as it no longer randomly one-shots everything), the Volt Buckler is still decently powerful. Plus, the demonstration now shows that you can actively switch weapons and still keep the shield up. The only major downside is that it still has a very limited pool of ammo (4 shots in total).

Well, here's something that's long overdue on my part. As many of you probably know, I once attempted to play a remake of Mega Man DOS - with "attempted" being the key word. I dropped the playthrough once I reached the fortress stages because, simply put, I felt it wasn't worth it as the game's faults only continued to pile up (and showed no signs of stopping, either). With that being said however, I'm all for giving games second chances if the creators show the initiative for improving their work.

Bit Man is definitely one of the more involved bosses in this game (that is, if you're facing his secondary form - which seems to be triggered by beating Volt Man first). It has three distinct phases to it, the last of which is actually pretty hectic due to him cloning himself (although thankfully, the clone seems to have a rather small amount of health).

Believe it or not, this game has actually become a rather solid example of such. The updated version has presented so many fixes and improvements over the original, to the point where it's actually kind of incredible to think that this is the same game. Granted, it still has its fair share of faults in a few places, but the good definitely outweighs the bad this time around.
